tn.text: After his opening greeting, James tells the believers that the purpose of trouble is to test faith.

tn.ref: James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ
tn.text: The phrase "I am" is implied. AT: "I, James, am a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
James was the half-brother of Jesus.

tn.ref: to the twelve tribes in the dispersion
tn.text: This expression refers either to all Jewish Christians living outside of Israel, or, more likely, to all Christians living anywhere in the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The term "twelve tribes" normally stood for all the people of Israel, because they had been divided into twelve tribes. In this passage, however, "twelve tribes" stands either for all Jewish Christians or, more likely, for all Christians everywhere in the world. Here "twelve tribes" is used as a title, and the number "twelve" should be written as text, not as a numeral. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The term "dispersion" normally referred to all Jews scattered in other countries, away from their homeland Israel. In this passage, however, "dispersion" stands either for all Jewish Christians living outside Israel, or, more likely, to all Christians everywhere in the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a basic greeting, such as "hello" or "good day"

tn.ref: Consider it all joy, my brothers, when you experience various troubles
tn.text: "My fellow believers, think of all your different kinds of troubles as something to celebrate"

tn.ref: the testing of your faith produces endurance
tn.text: The expressions "the testing," "your faith," and "endurance" are nouns that stand for actions. God does the testing, that is, he finds out how much the believers trust and obey him. Believers ("you") believe in him and endure suffering. AT: "when you suffer hardships, God is finding out how much you trust him. As a result, you will become able to endure even more hardships" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here endurance is spoken of as if it were a person at work. AT: "Learn to endure any hardship" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
able to trust in Christ and obey him in all circumstances
This can be stated in the positive. AT: "having all that you need" or "being all that you need to be"

tn.ref: ask for it from God, the one who gives
tn.text: "ask God for it. He is the one who gives"
"gives generously and does not rebuke"
"God will do it" or "God will answer your prayer"
This can be stated in the positive. AT: "with complete certainty that God will answer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: For anyone who doubts is like a wave in the sea that is driven by the wind and tossed around
tn.text: Anyone who doubts that God will help him is said to be like the water in the ocean or in large lakes, which keeps moving in different directions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

minded** - The word "double-minded" refers to a person's thoughts when he is unable to make a decision. AT: "cannot decide if he will follow Jesus or not" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here this person is spoken of as if he could not stay on one path but instead went from one to another. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the believer who does not have much money"
Someone whom God has honored is spoken of as if he were standing in a high place.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"but the man who has a lot of money." Possible meanings are 1) the rich man is a believer (UDB) or 2) the rich man is an unbeliever.
A rich believer should be happy if God brings him suffering. AT: "should be happy that God has given him that position" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: he will pass away as a wild flower in the grass
tn.text: Rich people are spoken of as being similar to wild flowers, which are alive for only a short time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: the rich man will fade away in the middle of his journey
tn.text: Here the flower simile is probably continued. As flowers do not die suddenly but instead fade away over a short time, so also the rich people may not die suddenly but instead take a little time to disappear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: in the middle of his journey
tn.text: A rich man's activites in daily life are spoken of as if they were a journey that he was making. This metaphor implies that he has given no thought to his coming death, and that it instead takes him by surprise. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
James reminds the believers who have fled that God does not cause temptation; he tells them how to avoid temptation.
Fortunate, Well-off
remains faithful to God during hardships
he has been approved by God
Eternal life is spoken of as if it were a wreath of leaves placed on the head of a victorious athlete. AT: "receive eternal life as his reward" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: has been promised to those who love God
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God has promised the crown of life to those who love him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"when he desires to do something evil"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God is trying to make me do something evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: God is not tempted by evil
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God does not desire to do anything evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: nor does he himself tempt anyone
tn.text: "and God himself does not try to make anyone do evil"

tn.ref: each person is tempted by his own desire
tn.text: A person's desire is spoken of as if it were someone else who was tempting him to sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: which drags him away and entices him
tn.text: Evil desire continues to be spoken of as if it were a person who could drag away someone else. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
attracts, persuades someone to do evil

tn.ref: Then after the desire conceives, it gives birth to sin. And after the sin is full grown, it gives birth to death
tn.text: Desire continues to be spoken of as a person, this time clearly as a woman who becomes pregnant with a child. The child is identified as sin. Sin is another female baby that grows up, becomes pregnant, and gives birth to death. This chain of metaphors is a picture of someone who ends up dying both spiritually and physically because of his evil desires and his sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Do not let anyone deceive you" or "Stop deceiving yourselves" (UDB)

tn.ref: Every good gift and every perfect gift
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. James uses them to emphasize that anything good that a person has comes from God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
God, the creator of all the lights in the sky (sun, moon, and stars), is said to be their "Father." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: With him there is no changing or shadow because of turning
tn.text: This expression pictures God as an unchanging light, in contrast to the sun, moon, planets, and stars, which move across the sky and are always changing in their brightness. AT: "God does not change like the sun, moon, and stars, which appear and disappear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The word "us" refers to James and his audience. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
God, who brought us eternal life, is spoken of as if he had given us birth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The true message of God. This is spoken of as if it were the means by which God "gave us birth."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

James is using the traditional Hebrew idea of first fruits as a way to describe the value of the Christian believers to God. He implies that there will be many more believers in the future. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Possible meaning are 1) "Know this" as a command, to pay attention to what I am about to write or 2) "You know this" as a statement, that I am about to remind you of something that you already know.

tn.ref: let every man be quick to hear, slow to speak
tn.text: People should first listen intently, and then consider carefully what they say. "Slow to speak" does not mean speaking slowly.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"not get angry easily"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the anger of man does not work the righteousness of God
tn.text: When a person gets angry, he cannot do God's work, which is righteous.

tn.ref: put away all sinful filth and abundance of evil
tn.text: Sin and evil are spoken of here as if they were objects that could be put aside or thrown away. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: take off all sinful filth and abundant amounts of evil
tn.text: Here the expressions "sinful filth" and "evil" share similar meanings. James uses them to emphasize how bad sin is. AT: "stop doing every kind of sinful behavior" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here "filth," that is, dirt, stands for sin and evil. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Without pride" or "Without arrogance"

The expression "implant" means to place one thing inside of another. Here God's word is spoken of as if it were a plant made to grow inside believers. AT: "obey the message God has spoken to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "word," that is, God's word, stands for the message of salvation in Christ Jesus that God speaks to believers. When they believe it, God saves them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
What a person is saved from can be made explicit. AT: "save you from God's judgment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here the word "souls" refers to persons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
They are to obey what God's word commands.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"fooling yourselves"

tn.ref: For if anyone is a hearer of the word but not a doer, he is like a man who examines his natural face in a mirror
tn.text: A person who hears God's word but does not obey it is said to be like someone who looks in the mirror and then forgets what he looks like. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
his face as it actually is

tn.ref: He examines himself ... and immediately forgets
tn.text: The man who looks at his face and immediately forgets what he saw is the like the man who hears the word of God and forgets what he heard.

tn.ref: the person who looks carefully into the perfect law
tn.text: This expression continues the image of the law as a mirror.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"the perfect law that allows people to be free"

tn.ref: this man will be blessed in his actions
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will bless this man as he obeys the law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"thinks he worships God correctly"
Controlling one's tongue stands for controlling one's speech. AT: "what he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"fools" or "misleads"
Here "heart" refers to his belief or thoughts. AT: "himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2: translate:figs_metonymy]])
"he worships God uselessly"

James speaks of religion, the way one worships God, as if it could be physically clean and spotless. These are traditional ways for Jews to say that something is acceptable to God. AT: "Completely acceptable" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
directed to God (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the orphans"
The women who are suffering because their husbands have died.

tn.ref: to keep oneself spotless from the world
tn.text: to not allow the evil in the world to cause oneself to sin (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
